body.p: These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Lily Irene Crimmins to John D. Crimmins

body.p: 9-year-old Lily Crimmins writes to her father - "I read in the Times that gentlemen ought to vote for Roosevelt and save the City from the robbers."

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Civil and military governors have been asked for lists of towns in each province. The replies have been partially tabulated and appear largely untrustworthy.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Winthrop Chanler to Theodore Roosevelt

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Winthrop Chanler suggests that President Roosevelt "direct" Andrew Carnegie to purchase a building for donation to the Smithsonian or the Boone and Crockett Club. He mentions having seen William Sturgis Bigelow and Dan Wister.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: The Metcalf Appointment And The Future

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: The appointment of Wilder Stevens Metcalf as pension agent shows that Senator Burton's influence and Senatorial privilege will be respected by President Roosevelt. With this issue decided, Kansas Republicans should ignore factionalism and unite as "good Republicans."

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Brief Summary of Lieut. Sims' Criticisms Contained in his Reports from the Asiatic Station

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Summary of reports from Lieutenant Sims regarding the defects of the U.S.S. Kentucky when compared to the designs and target practice results of Royal Navy vessels.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Article argues that Edgar Stanton Maclay was unfairly discharged from his government position for a section of his book disparaging Admiral Schley.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Brooks Adams to George B. Cortelyou

body.p: Brooks Adams accepts an invitation to the White House.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Review of the political wrangling and infighting over the appointment of Pension Agent at Topeka, Kansas.

field.name: Original.SubjectTags

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from John M. Carson to Milton E. Ailes

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: John M. Carson encloses a clipping that he would like forwarded to Secretary Gage. In a handwritten note, Gage sends the letter and clipping to President Roosevelt.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from W. S. Conlin to Theodore Roosevelt

body.p: W. S. Conlin returns the letter and memo from William Sowden Sims. Conlin thinks that Sims is an alarmist but also wants him to be encouraged to improve naval gunnery and target practice.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

field.name: Original.SubjectTags
field.value: United States. Navy Dept. Bureau of Navigation

body.p: These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: The Old Soldiers Are All Right

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: The "old soldiers" opposed the initial appointment of Cyrus Leland as pension agent and supported the recent appointment of Wilder Stevens Metcalf as Leland's replacement.

field.name: Original.SubjectTags

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Charles S. Fairchild to Theodore Roosevelt

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Charles S. Fairchild has copied the letter to Captain Campbell and the team. He had a pleasant evening at the club and accepts an invitation to have lunch at the White House.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Patrick Ford to Theodore Roosevelt

body.p: Patrick Ford writes on behalf of his friend, Richard C. Kerens, who has been maligned in the press.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Arthur Twining Hadley to Theodore Roosevelt

body.p: President Hadley of Yale sends a reprint of John Carlyle's translation of Dante which they had discussed at Mr. Farnam's dinner.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

Cartoon depicts a bear named Platt chasing William Allen White, who has dropped his gun and is running the other direction. The gun is titled McClure, the magazine in which White published a blistering critique of Thomas Platt. Caption: The King of Boyville, his Zulu rifle, and a very savage bear in the New York woods.

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Theodor von Holleben to John Hay

field.name: Original.Period
field.value: President of the United States - First Term (September 1901-February 1905)

body.p: Baron Herman, agricultural expert of the German embassy, has been transferred to Germany and would like to pay his respects to President and Mrs. Roosevelt before his departure.

These images are presented through a cooperative effort between the Library of Congress and Dickinson State University. See the Theodore Roosevelt Digital Library Terms of Use for further copyright information.

field.name: Original.Title
field.value: Letter from Seth Low to Theodore Roosevelt

body.p: Seth Low, soon to be Mayor of New York City, requests President Roosevelt's opinion on several potential appointments.
